oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Victory on Lake Erie
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A colored print of Commodore O.H. Perry's Victory on Lake Erie, 1813. A rowboat floats in between a fleet of ships. In the rowboat is an officer standing and holding a sword. Several men have oars. Additional information on back of print.

From the Franklin D. Roosevelt Naval Collection. (The Old Navy I, 1799-1815). The Battle of Lake Erie took place off the coast of Ohio on September 10, 1813. It was a major victory for the U. S. Navy fleet in the War of 1812, and it gave the Americans full control of the lake. Two well-known phrases originated during the battle. "We have met the enemy and they are ours," and "Don't give up the ship!"
